verses.text: After the Philistines had captured the ark of God, they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
verses.comment: The Philistines, Israel's enemies, seize the ark. The ark represents God's presence among His people. Note parallels to times when God's presence departs due to sin (Ezek. 10:18-19).

verses.text: The Philistines took the ark of God and brought it into the temple of Dagon and set it beside Dagon.
verses.comment: Placing the ark in Dagon's temple suggests they viewed the God of Israel as subordinate or captive. This foreshadows coming judgment on false gods; see Is. 46:1 and Phil. 2:10, where all creation must bow to the true God.

verses.text: Early the next morning, when the people of Ashdod came into the temple of Dagon, they found Dagon fallen with his face to the ground before the ark of the Lord. They took Dagon and set him back in his place.
verses.comment: Dagon bowing before the ark shows the supremacy of Israel’s God. See also Ps. 97:7 ('all gods bow down before him'). The physical act points to a spiritual reality: all idols collapse before the true presence.

verses.text: But the next morning, when they rose early, Dagon had fallen again, face down before the ark of the Lord. This time, Dagon's head and both hands were broken off, lying on the threshold; only the trunk of Dagon was left.
verses.comment: The destruction is even greater here. The broken head and hands signify complete defeat (Judg. 8:6). This prefigures Christ’s ultimate triumph over all powers (Col. 2:15).

verses.text: That is why, even to this day, the priests of Dagon and all who enter Dagon's house in Ashdod do not step on the threshold.
verses.comment: The memory of the ark’s power leaves a lasting mark on pagan practice. Notice how even the enemies of Israel are changed by contact with God’s holiness—a theme that’s echoed throughout salvation history.

verses.text: The hand of the Lord was heavy against the people of Ashdod. He devastated them and struck them with tumors, both in Ashdod and its surrounding territory.
verses.comment: The ‘hand of the Lord’ imagery demonstrates divine judgment (cf. Exod. 9:3). This episode underlines God's holiness and the consequences of disrespecting what is sacred. Early traditions see the tumors as marking impurity and the need for purity when approaching the divine—note the parallels to New Testament calls for holiness before God (Heb. 12:28-29).

verses.text: When the people of Ashdod saw what was happening, they said, 'The ark of the God of Israel must not stay with us, for his hand is severe against us and against Dagon our god.'
verses.comment: The Philistines recognize the supernaturality of Israel’s God, connecting the plague with the presence of the ark. There is a recognition—even among nonbelievers—of the reality and holiness of Israel’s God (see Dan. 2:47).

verses.text: So they summoned all the rulers of the Philistines and asked, 'What shall we do with the ark of the God of Israel?' They replied, 'Let the ark be moved to Gath.' So they moved the ark of the God of Israel there.
verses.comment: The inability of the Philistines to escape divine judgment by merely relocating God's presence shows that God is sovereign over all nations. This foreshadows the universal reach of salvation that comes to fullness in Christ (Luke 2:32).

verses.text: After they had brought it to Gath, the hand of the Lord was against that city and struck it with a very great panic. He afflicted the men of the city, both young and old, so that tumors broke out on them.
verses.comment: The persistent plague in each city underscores the universality of God's sovereignty and the inescapability of His justice. Judgment falls on all ages, showing the inherited nature of sin (Rom. 5:12).

verses.text: So they sent the ark of God to Ekron. But as soon as the ark entered Ekron, the people cried out, 'They have brought the ark of the God of Israel to kill us and our people!'
verses.comment: The panic and fear among the Philistines reveal a consciousness of their own inadequacy before the God of Israel. The narrative illustrates God’s glory is not to be taken lightly, and true worship requires reverence and respect, something later fulfilled in the New Covenant principles of worship.

verses.text: So they gathered together all the rulers of the Philistines and said, 'Send the ark of the God of Israel away; let it go back to its own place, so that it does not kill us and our people.' For there was a deadly panic throughout the whole city; the hand of God was very heavy there.
verses.comment: They beg to return the ark, acknowledging its holiness is too great to dwell casually among them. The humble response suggests a dawning realization that the presence of God demands a right relationship and preparation—hinting at deeper realities fulfilled when access to God is restored through the true and living way (see Heb. 10:19-22).

verses.text: Those who did not die were struck with tumors, and the outcry of the city went up to heaven.
verses.comment: This verse concludes with the city’s lament rising heavenward, echoing Israel's cries in Egypt (Exod. 3:7). Throughout salvation history, God hears the cries of afflicted people. In light of Christ, we recall that true healing and reconciliation are found in approaching God with humility, with the fullness of God's presence available not merely in symbols but in reality (John 1:14; Heb. 9:11-12).
